section.heading: Argument of Richard O. Burst, Sr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Hudson v. Louisiana.
Mr. Burst.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

The case that I present to the Court today, I think, is limited in issue and scope, and briefly stated, simply involves where a trial court in Louisiana after hearing the evidence, sustained a motion for a new trial on the basis of insufficient evidence and the defendant was retried.
Subsequently, before appeal became final, this Court rendered a decision in Burks v. United States.
The case was taken to the Louisiana Supreme Court on a writ, first by writ of habeas corpus to the district court, and then by writ of habeas corpus to the Louisiana Supreme Court on certiorari.
The Supreme Court issued an opinion denying our relief after accepting cert and that's what brings us to this Court.
We take issue with the ruling of the Supreme Court of Louisiana basically on two areas where I feel that they have based their opinion on two faulty premises.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Did that court have Burks before it when it decided the case?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: It did when it decided the writ of certiorari on the specific issue.
The issue before them was limited, as it is now, precisely and only to the double jeopardy question.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Justice Dennis begins his dissent with a citation to Burks, does he not?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: That is correct.
And I argued Burks completely.
Now, Jackson had not been issued, but Burks was before them.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, we take our State procedure and state procedural remedies as we find them in this Court.
And it would appear to me that from Justice Tate's opinion and from the majority opinion, they treat the motion that was made as a 13th-juror type of motion, which Burks left open.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: They do treat it, but they treat it on the same basis as this Court discussed in Jackson v. Virginia.
In other words, they applied it on a no evidence versus insufficient evidence.

In fact, in the first page, the first two pages of the opinion of the Supreme Court of Louisiana, they set forth the issue of Burks as rendered by the Chief Justice of this Court and then they set forth the issue before them and they use exactly the same language, only they rule contrary to what this Court did.
I can point that out.
It's in the Appendix, 49a.
Justice Blanche quoted it in the Supreme Court of Louisiana.
In the first paragraph he uses the term,
"solely for lack of sufficient evidence to sustain the jury's verdict. "
Then, on page 48, in reference to discussing Burks, he states that this Court decided and reversed on the issue of solely for lack of sufficient evidence to sustain the jury's verdict.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, then you would have to disavow Justice Tate's concurring opinion, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Yes, I would.
I further... I feel that also in Justice Tate's concurring opinion that he simply states facts that were not mentioned by the trial judge in his ruling.
I think the trial judge's ruling is concise and if there is any ambiguity at all in the trial judge's ruling, it would be by virtue of the precise language he used where he said that
"I viewed the same evidence, that in the present case I heard the same evidence the jury did. "
"I am convinced that there was no evidence, certainly not evidence beyond a reasonable doubt to sustain the verdict of homicide committed by the defendant on this particular victim. "
and the only ambiguity there is whether he was applying a no evidence rule or insufficient evidence beyond a reasonable doubt.
And I think that that's really a difference without a distinction, that he--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Well, wasn't he saying in the alternative I see no evidence whatever, but if I'm wrong on that then my fallback position is, there was not evidence beyond a reasonable doubt?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --That's correct.
And I feel--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Burst, isn't that even ambiguous, because can't one read that to mean, either not sufficient evidence from which a jury could have no reasonable doubt, on the basis of which a jury could find guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, or not sufficient evidence to convince me, the judge, beyond a reasonable doubt?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --I think that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: I mean, you could read it either way, couldn't you?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --I have to just take the words as they're spoken.
I was not--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, which way does it mean?

Does it mean he doesn't think there's enough evidence to convince him beyond a reasonable doubt, or not enough to have submitted to the jury, and if he means the latter why did he submit it to the jury?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --Well, I have two answers to that question.
Louisiana laws that existed then did not permit a trial judge to withhold the submission to the jury.
In 1975, and prior to that time... and I have both sections cited in my brief... prior to '75 there was an ability of the trial judge to, in effect, sustain a motion for directed verdict.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Did they have authority to enter a judgment notwithstanding verdict at that time?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Not at the time of this trial they did not.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Well, at the time of this trial, couldn't the judge at the end of the trial have said what he said to himself here, and therefore I am entering judgment for the defendant of acquittal notwithstanding the verdict?
Could he do that at that time?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: No, sir.
The first and only vehicle that a defendant has in Louisiana to raise the issue of insufficient evidence is a motion for new trial, and that's it.
And that was the law at the time this was tried, that is subsequent--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But Justice Tate had been a member of that Court for many years.
Wouldn't you expect him to have known that if that were in fact the case?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --I'm not sure I understand your question.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I mean, it seems to me he is saying that what the trial judge did is to say that the question the trial judge answered was the one posed by Justice Stevens or by the Chief Justice.
But there was not enough evidence here to satisfy me, had I been sitting as a juror, beyond a reasonable doubt?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Well, that would be the second part of my answer to Justice Stevens.
And that would be that even if that's what he was saying, that's what the law required him to do, and specifically, precisely that.
In other words, if at that point in time, if in his opinion there was insufficient evidence, then he was to so hold.
And by so holding he has placed the case in a position where it cannot be retried under our Constitution.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Well, then you're saying, I take it, that a statute which required a judge to submit this question to the jury when there was in fact no evidence, would in itself be unconstitutional.
Is that your position?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: No, sir.
It would not be, because I feel that there is no constitutional guarantee of a motion for directed verdict, or even for an appeal for that matter.
I feel that as long as all people are treated alike, it makes no difference.

All I'm saying is that in this case, in Louisiana law, there is no motion for directed verdict available to the defendant in a jury trial and the first time, by their law, that he can raise the issue of insufficient evidence is on motion for new trial.
I don't think that that in and of itself is unconstitutional, but I do feel that in this case that the ruling of the trial judge could not have been clearer.
Indeed, the entire ruling which is transcribed for the Court, it sets the basis for his ruling, what he observed, and the factual basis.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: You have to treat his statement, then, as Mr. Justice Stevens pointed out, as a statement that no reasonable juror could reasonably find guilt on the evidence, don't you?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I do.

And I feel that... when I say the double, I say that, doubly, that what I feel is the faulty premises that the Louisiana court bases its decision on, is that is one, is that certainly one cannot read the trial judge's statement, his opinion, and it is clear what he is ruling.
At the very outside he is saying there was insufficient evidence beyond a reasonable doubt to convict this man.
That would be taking his statement most favorably to the State's position.
I say he still, even with that finding, that there is no retrial, or should be none.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But he granted a new trial.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Yes, sir, and the existing law, at that time, in even the State I'm from, that was the law.
If they... in effect, what they were saying was, if you move for a new trial, you waive the argument to your constitutional double jeopardy.
But I think that is particularly innocuous here, because under Louisiana law it was the only vehicle he had.

You know, if you're requiring a man, he can't waive that issue until a motion for a new trial, and then at the same time, you're saying, but if you do raise it you waive your double jeopardy argument.
And that's why I think that this particular statutory system is possibly unconstitutional.

If it were applied in a meaning where you said, because I asked for a new trial, I do waive my right to raise double jeopardy, then I think it's unconstitutional, as requiring him to choose between two constitutional safeguards.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Well, in a motion for a new trial for error in the admission or rejection of evidence, is there a waiver of any double jeopardy claimed there?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: No, sir, because double jeopardy does, as this Court clearly set out in Burks, that that is not a jeopardy question, where it's an error of law, and where it's simply both sides need a different, or a new chance to put on and correct that error.
But this Court has, I think, clearly said in Burks that where there's a failure to muster sufficient evidence the state doesn't get a second chance.
And in this case is what they got, and indeed they came forth at the second trial with an eyewitness, ten months later.

The second position, I think, that is... again, I will use this term "faulty premise" that the Louisiana Supreme Court is using, is simply that they are attempting to apply the no evidence rule on both ends.
On one end they're saying the trial judge says, merely insufficient evidence.
And I would say, and my argument is that that is, when you say it's insufficient beyond a reasonable doubt, you've said it all.

But then, on the other hand, to try to apply the no evidence rule under existing Louisiana procedure, and say, because we have a dichotomy between no evidence and insufficient evidence that we are not going to apply, in essence, the Burks decision of the standard of reasonable doubt, as In Re: Winship.
I think there, from both ends, that their premise is faulty.

And I would assert that as recently as 1980, May of 1980, the court of Louisiana, the Supreme Court of Louisiana, has maintained their position, and that is, they have said that in the case of... if I may have a drink of water.
In May of 1980, in the State v. Custard... it's the state court of Louisiana, they stated then that
"This court has yet fully to embrace Jackson v. Virginia. "

And that's where this Court, I think, laid to rest the dichotomy between the no evidence rule and the application of the rule of insufficient evidence beyond a reasonable doubt, and adopted, and indeed said that even on federal, and I recognize that Jackson is a very limited opinion, and it's limited to habeas corpus review by federal district judges.

Now, I think this case that is now before this Court here is the next logical sequence, or logical step, in applying that standard in requiring the states through the Fourteenth and the Fifth Amendments to adhere to that standard.
And the footnotes in this case by the Louisiana Supreme Court fully state that they haven't made up their mind whether or not they're going to follow that standard.
And I think that's what we're asking this Court to do is to give direction to the Supreme Court of Louisiana and advise them that they will have to embrace the reasonable doubt standard.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Burst, what if the trial judge had explicitly relied on Subsection, Subparagraph 5 of Article 851 in granting the new trial?
You would not then claim that there was denial of?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: That is accurate; yes, sir.
I would not claim double jeopardy.
Let me get to my section here and make--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But you do disavow the concurring opinion in the rehearing?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --It's totally in the brief.
I think the wording of the trial judge could not have been clearer on what he was deciding it under.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, as Justice Stevens suggests, that his statement can be understood to mean that he as a so called 13th juror was not convinced beyond a reasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Well, the... at page 8a of the Appendix, I believe it is, he starts out, the trial judge fixes the issue himself.
He says,
"I believe I'm paraphrasing those grounds. "
However, "The argument was"--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Where are you reading now?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --Oh, I'm sorry.
I'm on 8a of the Appendix.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: And this is where the trial judge is discussing the motion for a new trial.
And about midway down, it begins,

"The argument was, however, that there was no evidence presented that would have justified the jury in finding the defendant guilty as charged because there was no evidence beyond a reasonable doubt before the jury of the essential elements to prove the essential elements of the crime. "
So he fixed the issue he was determining it on.
His discussion thereafter discusses that basis and his final statement is precisely, again, on it.

And I... perhaps I'm missing the direction of questioning, but I really feel that whether he's sitting as a 13th juror or what, at a point in time where a reviewing court, whether it be the trial judge or an appellate court, cites that the evidence was insufficient beyond a reasonable doubt and at the point in time that becomes final, I believe that the man is acquitted.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, if the trial judge didn't do it here, certainly the Supreme Court of Louisiana didn't do it here.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: The Supreme Court of Louisiana takes the position that under their laws that exist, they cannot review a decision unless there's a finding of no evidence at all.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, so you have to rely on the trial judge's conclusion to support your hypothesis that when a judge declares that no reasonable person could have found guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, that is the end of the case as far as double jeopardy, because certainly it is not the position of the Supreme Court of Louisiana.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: At this point, that is accurate.

But if this Court were to require the Supreme Court of Louisiana to adhere to the standard of not guilty or of insufficient evidence beyond a reasonable doubt, then it's only by case law that they have interpreted into their cases the standard of no evidence.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that's true of 49 other states too.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Well, in Oklahoma... that might be accurate, I don't know.
I know, in Oklahoma, we never use the new evidence v. the insufficient evidence split.
In other words, it's strictly and always has been whether or not the evidence was sufficient beyond a reasonable doubt.
But--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Burst, you did not try this case?
Did you try this case?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --No, sir, I did not.
In fact, I was not retained until after, or brought into the case until after the appeal.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: What if this truly were... and I think you have just told us you don't think there's any difference if it's a 13th juror basis on which a new trial was granted, or a basis of a finding that there was insufficient evidence to convince any reasonable triers of fact beyond a reasonable doubt.
But I thought... isn't that inconsistent with your answer to my question when I asked you if the court had, the trial court had explicitly relied on Subparagraph 5?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Perhaps I am confused with this Subparagraph 5--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That you would not be making this claim?
Subparagraph 5 of Article 851.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --That's correct.
If he had strictly relied on Subparagraph 5, then I would say I would not be before this Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: In other words, one can imagine a state... I doubt that there is one, but there may be... which said that anybody convicted of a criminal offense in a trial court is entitled to a new trial as his right, just to entitle them to two bites at the apple.
And so a person is convicted and he makes his motion for a new trial and he's granted a new trial.
There's no double jeopardy attached to that, is there?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: I would say that that would, one, that they'd have to determine, and I'm not--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: He simply relies on that state law that entitles him to a second trial if he's convicted at the first trial.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --No double jeopardy?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: None at all.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And wouldn't the same thing be true if the new trial were granted under Subparagraph 5?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: I thought that was the question.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Yes, it was.
And I thought you answered, yes, it would be.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: In Subparagraph 5, the court made a finding,
"It is of the opinion the ends of justice would be better served by granting a new trial although defendant may be entitled to a new trial as a matter of. "

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: "May not be entitled to a new trial. "

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --"May not be".
Then I would not be before this Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Right.

Or, if a state... and some states do do this... empower the trial judge to grant a new trial, if he, the trial judge, as a juror sitting in the box was not convinced beyond a reasonable doubt of the defendant's guilt, regardless of any finding as to what 12 other reasonable men might have been convinced of.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: I would have to look at that specific statute, Your Honor.
I feel that if it were worded similar to this, that double jeopardy would not be an issue unless it were used as a subterfuge.
Then I think it could still be raised.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, the defendant would hardly use it as a subterfuge.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: That's correct.
If the defendant moved on, if he specifically said, I want a new trial on number five then yes, I totally agree with you.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Unless, in fact, there were no evidence in the record of guilt.

Say the judge just put it on Section 5, but then the defendant argued, well, he granted it for that reason, but they didn't offer any evidence of guilt at all, and on review of the record you concluded that was right.
Could there be a new trial?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: If the trial judge concluded that there was no evidence at all--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: He doesn't conclude anything.
The trial judge says, I'm going to grant a Section 5 new trial; in the interest of justice, I wasn't persuaded.
But supposing a federal judge looking at the case later or the reviewing court finds there's absolutely no evidence of guilt in the record at all; they didn't even put a witness on the stand.
Could he be retried?
Is the test what the record shows or what the judge says?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --I think the test often is what the finding, the ultimate finding of the court, is.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: You mean, if the judge says, it's a new trial under Section 5 in the interests of justice, there could be a new trial, even if the state put in no evidence of guilt at all, didn't put a single witness on the stand?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: No, that's what I would... that was my point in answering.
If the Rule 5 grant were, in my words, a subterfuge, or actually what the motion was that there was insufficient evidence, then I don't think there could be a new trial.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: So the test is what the record shows, not what the judge says?
And it's up to this Court to independently examine the record, is that it?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: No, I didn't say that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, what did you say?
You can't have it both ways.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: No, I don't ask for it both ways.
I don't ask; this is not my role.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, what do you say?
Is it what the judge says or what the record says?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: What I say is, when at some point, when the judge of whatever system it is, in this case the State of Louisiana, when the judge who sits on the issue makes his finding and that finding becomes final through either appeal or lack thereof, that that's what we have here at this Court and that this Court is not to review the record.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: No, but what if his finding is, I'm granting this motion under Section 5 in the interest of justice.
Is there always permitted to be a new trial?
You see, the other side of the coin is, here he used the language you like.
There's no evidence.
But Justice Tate said, no, but I've looked at the record and there is evidence in the record that was sufficient to go to the jury.
Do you agree with Justice Tate when he says that?
He doesn't turn on what the judge says.
He says there was enough evidence in the record to be submitted to the jury.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: First of all, I would take exception, and I do take exception, to Justice Tate's going into the record on an issue of law.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, I understand.
Your opinion is, we just look at what the trial judge says and we don't pay any attention to the record.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: It's final.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: But you conceded that the judge's comment was somewhat ambiguous, did you not?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Only to the point of whether or not he was finding no evidence, or on insufficient evidence beyond a reasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Let me pursue that with one more question.

Are you telling us that whenever a judge, a trial judge... forget the old Louisiana statute... any trial judge, who disagrees with the jury's verdict of guilt because as a juror he would have voted the other way, then, that gives rise to a double jeopardy problem?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Just because he disagrees?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: If he is willing to make the ruling under the then law... as he did in this case, and that is subject to appeal; you know, it couldn't in this case but in future cases it could be... I realize that Louisiana has a problem right now, if this Court follows my ruling, but that's Louisiana's problem if their structure is not in line with the U.S. constitutional requirements.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that's not what Burks said, is it?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: No, sir.
Burks was not a state case.
I recognize that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Presumably the double jeopardy requirements since Benton v. Maryland have been the same for purposes of state and federal courts.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Not in Louisiana, I don't think, because... I don't know that.
Again, Louisiana's been using the no evidence versus insufficient evidence.
They've been saying, unless the trial judge will say there's no evidence of either the crime or an element of the crime, then we don't review it.
If there is... however, if it's merely insufficient evidence, then they will not review it.
Only if there's no evidence.
And that's where we... you know, the problem of review in Louisiana law lies--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: But xx only one question, namely, that the evidence does not support the verdict with evidence beyond a reasonable doubt.
Then, what is the test?
If there's a motion for a new trial on that ground, what's the test that the trial judge should apply?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --I think he should apply the test of whether or not that any trier of fact could find--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Could reasonably find?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --Could reasonably find.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: In other words, that's Justice Tate's... it would follow Justice Tate's theory?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: I don't read that into Justice Tate's theory.
I think what Justice Tate did was, he did not like what the trial judge said.
He inserted his opinion.
Let's point out that the Louisiana Supreme Court denied the appeal from the trial judge is sustaining of the motion for a new trial.
In other words, the trial judge made his ruling and the State took writs and the writs were denied.
And they were denied because of this Louisiana dichotomy.
Then, two years later, Tate comes behind... or Justice Tate goes behind that and says he examined the records and he's speaking for himself only, not the majority of the court.
He says that we would have affirmed, but he's speaking for himself only.
And he's going behind the record which, I'm told time and time again I can't do, when I come on appeal.
And I do take issue with that in the concurrent opinion; yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, but his opinion is not inconsistent with the action of the Supreme Court the first time around in refusing to reverse the order granting a new trial, because his theory of the order granting a new trial was that there was enough evidence to go to the jury, but that the interests of justice made it appropriate to grant a new trial.
There's nothing inconsistent with his view in affirming the... in other words, he says the order was right.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: It's inconsistent in that the standard applied is identical to the standard this Court has laid down in In Re: Winship, whereas the standard where, which the State of Louisiana is saying was merely insufficient evidence, is identical to the standard that this Court has laid down in In Re: Winship and recognized in Burks and later in Jackson v. Virginia.
And, you know, if they can say the same words and say they mean something else, then I would concur with the Court, with you.
But they're not.
I mean, they're using the same words, and particularly the majority of the court, they're using the exact same words as did the Chief Justice in saying they mean different things.
And I can't agree with that as a matter of law.
That's semantics.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If you wish to save any time for rebuttal, you have your--

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: I would like to, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --Mr. Bullers.

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
I agree with Mr. Burst that this really is limited and involves interpretation of the particular statutes that our Code of Criminal Procedure has dealing with new trials.
The State's position is that the trial judge, when he made the comment, he said that
"I heard the same evidence the jury did. "
Then he went on to say, "I'm convinced".
It does appear somewhat ambiguous, of course.
As I said, the State's position is that he was stating his opinion after he had heard the same evidence that the jury heard.
Now, the trial judge at that time didn't have the benefit of Burks and Jackson v. Virginia.
The problem that we run into is that in commenting on the evidence it would seem to the State that the best answer is, what does the record really reflect?
We have an article for a new trial which deals with five subsections, and though the judge may call up one subsection or another, he could be in error.
And really, it does appear that the test would be, what does the record really reflect?

Of course, the State's position was, we agree with Judge Tate that, although because the trial judge did not have the benefit of Burks and Jackson, he didn't articulate particularly and he did not assign one particular subsection or another.
But even if he had, isn't it really what the record reflects?
But at any rate, the... in the Supreme Court--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Do you agree, Mr. Bullers, that at the time of this trial the trial judge had no power whatever to direct a judgment of acquittal?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: --Yes, I agree with that, Your Honor.
I do.
At that time--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Even if he did find that there was no evidence whatsoever, the extent of his power was to grant a new trial as a matter of judgment of the court.

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: --Yes, sir, that's correct.
At that point, that's what it was.

That particular provision for directed verdict had been deleted prior to this trial, so that in essence the Louisiana Legislature had taken away that judge's authority to interject himself into the jury trial process.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Could a defendant after the receipt of a guilty verdict, without moving for a new trial, appeal his conviction?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Yes.
That remedy would be to take an appeal.
I think the issue comes down to what extent should the trial judge interject himself or be required to interject himself into the trial by jury process?
We have a jury of 12 peers that felt the evidence was sufficient was beyond a reasonable doubt.
The trial judge differed.
So, the only way that I could see logically would be to see what the record really shows.
Somebody... obviously, there's a difference there; that's obvious.
But the key is, how... to what extent should the trial judge interject himself into this process?
Should he be required to evaluate the evidence that the jury hears and then make a decision?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: You keep saying the trial judge injected himself in.
I thought he sat there by right of the Constitution of the State of Louisiana.

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: You keep saying the trial judge injected himself into the trial.

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Well, what I said was--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Do you really mean that word "injected"?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: --Interjected.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Do you mean that?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: No, I said, what I meant was, to what extent should he be required to get into the decision process when you have a jury trial?
Should he be required to evaluate the evidence and to what extent should he interject himself into it?
I didn't say he did in this case.
I'm just saying this is what it's going to boil down to.
You understand as, in other words, in the future--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: No, I heard you.

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: --Right.

In the future the procedure that we have now just says that at the conclusion of the trial then you have a right, if he's found guilty, as in this case, then he can take an appeal or ask for a new trial, because the section pertaining to directed verdicts was deleted.
I concede that, so that throughout this time was simply to raise it on appeal or request a new trial.
In this case it was by a new trial.
So the issue would be in the future, then, to what extent does the judge have to evaluate the evidence in the jury process, trial by jury process?
I'm not saying that he interjected himself in it in this case.
He followed the law that since he didn't have the... since Burks had not been rendered at that time, he didn't articulate much further.
He just had the one little paragraph of... one little excerpt that Mr. Burst talked about, and that was,
"I heard the same evidence the jury did. "
"I'm convinced that it doesn't show. "
et cetera.
As he said, "I'm convinced".

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Bullers, can I ask you another question about Louisiana procedure?
As I understand it, you've just confirmed he could not have granted a judgment of not guilty notwithstanding the verdict of the jury?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: And he also had a duty in advance of... he had to submit the case to the jury even if he thought there was insufficient evidence to go to the jury?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: The way that our Code of Criminal Procedure, Article 778, was at that time, it would only be by trial judge alone, of course.
If there was a jury trial, it would have to be submitted to the jury.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: And what about at the end of the prosecutor's case, could he have granted directed verdict at that point in the proceeding?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: No, he couldn't, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: So if he thought there was no evidence of guilt and that there'd been a total failure of proof, he would have had to do exactly what he did in this case?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Exactly.
He would have to grant a new trial.
Then we get back to, did he grant it under Subsection 1, which was... as the grounds for that is that the verdict was contrary to the law and evidence, or was it some other grounds?
And of course, Justice Tate in his opinion felt that it was more in the interest of justice.

The State from our point of view gave the defendant a fair trial and he was convicted by a jury of his peers, and the judge said, in his language, "I'm not convinced"... that's our interpretation of it... and granted a new trial, which was the procedure at that time, that was his remedy.
We agree to that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Is there anything at all in the record that supports Judge Tate's view that... and I know he's an awfully good judge and usually is pretty careful about what he does... but is there anything in the record to support his view that the judge relied on Section Five?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: No, Your Honor, the judge didn't state that.
Obviously, Judge Tate in his reviewing the entire case felt that's what it was.
He obviously differed in the opinion of the judge... that when the judge said there was no evidence then he clarified that and said, at least, or certainly not beyond a reasonable doubt.
Judge Tate obviously disagreed with that because he said he felt that the record showed sufficient evidence to give it to the jury.

So that, in his opinion, it should have been five instead of one, and it goes back to, since the trial judge didn't articulate, and even if he had it still seems that it's actually what the record shows.
I don't see any other way, unfortunately.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: What is the status of your procedure now?
Is there an option open to the judge to grant a directed verdict notwithstanding--

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Well, it's still as it is now, is my understanding also.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: --It's still the same way?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: If your procedure allowed a directed verdict, and the district and the trial judge entered a verdict of not guilty notwithstanding the judgment, would you say that would bar another trial?
That would clearly bar another trial, even if there was a--

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: There would be a finding of not guilty and in essence it would bar another trial.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: --So we just look at the judge's ruling in that case, and we wouldn't really look at the evidence at all?
That's right.

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Do you have any other questions?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Then the State has no appeal from an order granting a new trial?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: No, Your Honor, there is no appeal or review by the State, once the judge orders a new trial then we'd have to proceed on with a new trial.
There was no higher court to review what had gone on and why, and to make a ruling whether the judge was right or wrong.
So once he said that the new trial should be held, then we'd have to proceed on with the new trial.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But then you defended... after the second trial you got in your licks on whether the new trial order was right?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Well, after the second trial, he was convicted again.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Then he appealed.

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: And then he appealed and raised this issue.
And, of course, his position, I think, was that we get another bite at the apple.
I'm not sure that's accurate, of course, but that would satisfy the jury.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Was there new evidence presented in the second trial that was not present at the first?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Yes; yes.
I didn't handle the trial.
The record shows that there was another witness that was not available or not found that didn't testify at the first trial, that did testify at the second.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, are you defending the Supreme Court of Louisiana's rationale for its decision?
Are you just asking, or not?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: I think that Judge Tate's rationale was probably the most accurate.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Under Burks or what?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I think that, as I understand Burks, it would be, is there sufficient evidence to give it to the jury?
And I think that Judge Tate considered that, and determined that there was.
But of course, he had to look at the record to determine that, obviously.
He had to know what the evidence was.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Do you agree with him?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Yes, I do.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Shouldn't we remand it, then, for the Supreme Court to apply the right standard and determine whether there was double jeopardy?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: That is a possibility.
As I understand the majority opinion, what they were saying was that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, if you agree with Tate, what else can you do except remand?
In other words, you're saying that the... are you saying?
that the Louisiana Supreme Court judgment cannot stand except on Judge Tate's theory?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: --His theory, as I said, appears to be the most accurate.
The majority opinion, I think, when they were sorting through Burks and applying it here, got into a difficult position.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: They just misread Burks, you think?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Or do you agree with that, or not?

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: --Of course, that is our Supreme Court, and those are learned gentlemen down there, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: And you hesitate to appear before them after having?
Of course, even Judge Tate isn't there anymore.

turn.speaker: james_m_bullers
turn.label: Mr. James M. Bullers
turn.text: No, that's correct, Your Honor.
He's with the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals now.

But if it does come down to the fact that this constitutes double jeopardy, then I think that as you read our statutes, then, Article 851, which sets out the various subdivisions, the judge is going to have to articulate particularly which one and why.
And as I said, the trial judge didn't have that benefit at the time.
So that's why we're sort of at a loss here.
I think that puts us in a difficult position.
I think that's true of the appellant as well as the State.
Does the Court have any other questions?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think not.
Do you have anything further, Mr. Burst?
You have two minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: They will be very brief, indeed.

First of all, I think if this Court looks at the entire opinion of the trial judge, that the trial judge... here is where I take issue with Justice Tate... in no way does the trial judge in any way state anything similar to the fifth provision of the Louisiana Code.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Richard O. Burst, Sr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: But did he say any more than that, if he had been a member of the jury, he would have voted the other way?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: He certainly did.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Oh, you think so?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: I certainly think he did and I specifically refer the Court to his reasoning.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: But an experienced trial judge should have articulated it more precisely if he meant what you say he meant?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Well, I think he did.
Because he went on to quote--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: The Supreme Court of Louisiana certainly agreed with you.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: --Excuse me, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: The Supreme Court of Louisiana agreed with you.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: Yes, they did.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Agreed with your reading of what the trial judge says.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: The majority did, yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Rightly or wrongly.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: But I... you know, I think he does say more than that, and in fact he does specifically reference three of the other grounds and... as I recall.
But that's in the Appendix for the Court to read, and that is, certainly, you know, where he ended up.

But I would point out that at the time that the trial... at the pleadings... we had it today... if the trial judge makes a ruling, then the motion for retrial on grounds of insufficient evidence beyond a reasonable doubt, that the State of Louisiana is in the same position it was then unless it is reversed in this Court.
And that is, that if there is an appeal by the State on a writ, they'll deny it because they're still applying the no evidence test and saying, we can't review it unless there's no evidence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Or as a matter of state law, the Supreme Court has, never reviews the sufficiency of the evidence, I gather.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That's a matter of the state statute, isn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: That's a matter of... I think it is statute by interpretation of the Constitution.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: I just read it here; yes.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: That is correct.
They're saying, what they're saying is, it doesn't arrive to a legal issue until you can point out that there's no evidence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In other words, the Supreme Court of Louisiana has no power to review the sufficiency of the evidence, as a matter of state law.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: They could, by interpretation, though.
See, they've interpreted... they themselves have interpreted the Constitution to say that.
In other words, their Constitution says says they can only review matters of law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: If they say that's what their Constitution means, that's what their Constitution means, as far as we're concerned.
We can't say differently.

turn.speaker: richard_o_burst
turn.label: Mr. Richard O. Burst, Sr.
turn.text: I understand.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
The case is submitted.
